sp.p: Out you naughty Wench, do you say I am old?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: No indeed, I did not name old.

sp.speaker: Mistris Troubles.
sp.p: Then let me tell you, that those women that are in years, seek company to divulge their Wit, as youth to divulge their Beauty; and we Aged Wits may chance to catch a Lover from a young Beauty: But I should applaud my own wit, if it could contrive to bring each Bride and Bridegroom into one Assembly, making Hymen's Monarchy a Republick, where all should be in common.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: So Mistriss you would prove a Traytor to Hymen, which is a Bawd.

sp.speaker: Mistris Troubles.
sp.p: Faith I will turn you away for your boldness.

div.stage: O Mistris Gossip you are welcome, what Newes!

sp.speaker: Mistris Gossip.
sp.p: I am come to tell you, that the five Bridals meet with their Guests and good Cheer at the City-Hall, and make their several Compa|nies Joyning as one, as one Body, and there will be such Revelling, as the like was never before.

sp.speaker: Mistris Troubles.
sp.p: Iuno be thanked, and Venus be praised for it; for I was much perplex'd concerning their Divisions, till you came and brought me this good Newes of their Corporation.

div.head: Scene 31.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Title, and the Lady Virtue as his Bride, both of them richly attired, and Old Humanity following them.

sp.speaker: LOrd Title.
sp.p: Come Old Humanity, and be our Father, to ioyn and give us in the Church; and then when we are Maried, we will live a Country-life, I as a Shepherd, and this Lady as my Fair Shepherdess.

div.head: Scene 32.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Ward as a Bride, and her Nurse Nurse Careful.

sp.speaker: NUrse Careful.
sp.p: My dear Child, you appear as a sweet budding Rose this morning.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Roses are beset with thorns, Nurse, I hope I am not so.

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: By'r Lady your Husband may prove a thorn, if he be not a good man, and a kind Husband; but Oh my heart doth ake.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Wherefore doth it ake?

div.stage: Enter Lord Courtship as a Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: Come Sweet, are you ready? for it is time to go to Church, it is almost twelve a clock.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: I am ready, but my Nurse doth affright me, by telling me her heart doth ake, as if she did fore-know by her experien'd age some ill for|tune towards me, or that I shall be unhappy in my mariage.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: Her heart doth not ake for you, but for her self, because she cannot be a young fair bride, as you are, as being past her youth; so that her heart doth ake out of a sad remembrance of her self, not for a present, or a future cause for you.

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: Well, well, I was young indeed, and a comely bride when I was maried, though I say it, and had a loving bridegroom, Heaven rest his soul.

div.head: Scene 33.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Visitant as a Bride, to the Lady Con|plation, another Bride.

sp.speaker: LAdy Visit.
sp.p: Come, I have brought all my bridal guests hither to joyn with yours, for we will go to Church together: Wherefore prethee come away, our Bridegrooms and our Guests stay for you.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: I will go to them by and by.

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: Why, I hope you do not stay to muse upon Phantasmes, saith Mariage will banish them out of your head, you must now imploy your time with Realities.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: If I thought Mariage would destroy or disturb my Con|templations, I would not marry, although my Wedding-guests were come, and my Wedding-dinner ready drest, and my Wedding-cloaths on; nay, were I at the holy Altar, I would return back.

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: That would be such an action, as all the Kingdome would say you were mad.

sp.speaker: Lady Contem.
sp.p: I had rather all the World should not only say I were mad, but think me so, rather than my self to be unhappy.

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: Can want of Contemplation make you unhappy?

sp.speaker: Lady Contem.
sp.p: Yes, as unhappy as a body can be without a soul; for Con|templation is the life of the soul, and who can be happy that hath a dead soul?

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: By my troth I had rather be dead, than have such a dull life.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, the Bridegroom is coming hither.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: I will prevent him, and meet him.

sp.speaker: 1 GEntlem.
sp.p: Come away, come away, they'l be all married before we shall get to Church.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentlem.
sp.p: There will be enough Witnesses, we may well be spared; but so I share of the Feast, I care not whether they be married or not.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentle.
sp.p: The truth is, the benefit to us will be only in eating of their meat, and drinking of their wine.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentlem.
sp.p: And I mean to be drunk, but not for joy of their Mariages, but for pleasure of my Gusto.

div.head: Scene 35.
div.stage: Enter the five Couples, and all the Bridal Guests: The Bride|grooms and the Brides dance, and the while the Bridal Torches are held in their hands: Then a `Poet speaks thus to them.

sp.speaker: Speaker.
sp.l: What Lines of Light doe from those Torches spin,
Which winds about those Ladies whiter skin?
But from their Eyes more Splend'rous Beams doe run,
As bright as those that issue from the Sun.
Wherein the lesser Lights wax dull and dim,
Or like as Minnes in an Ocean swim.

sp.speaker: MAll Mean-bred.
sp.p: By your good leave Gentlefolks, The Lord Maquiss writ this Scene I am come here to complain of this Hog-grubber Sir Golden Riches, who did tempt me with Gold till he had his desire, you know all what it is, and I like an honest woman, as it were, kept my word, and performed truly as any woman could do: Speak, canst thou detect me either in word or deed? and like a false and covetous wretch as thou art, performed nothing with me as thou shouldst have done, I am sure of that: Is't not a truth? speak coverous wretch, speak.

sp.speaker: Sir Gold. Rich.
sp.p: Why, what did I promise you?

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: Why thou didst promise me an hundred pounds in gold, shew'd it me, and then took it away again; nay further, thou saidst I should be a Lady, and have a great parimanus Coach gilt, with neighing Horses, and a Coachman, with a Postilion to ride afore: Nay, nay, I remember well e|nough what you said, you talkd of Gesemond, Pomatum, and Roman Gunpow|der for my hair, and fine gowns and stockings, and sine lac'd silk garters, and roses shining like Stars, God bless us!

sp.speaker: Sir Gold. Rich.
sp.p: Did I, did I?

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: Yes, that you did, you know what you did, and how you did, and so do I; and Gentlefolks as I am a true woman, which he knows I am, I never had more than this white fustion wastecoat, and three pence to buy me three penyworth of pins, for he would allow me no incle to tie it withall, and this old stamel peticoat, that was his great Grand|mothers in Eighty eight, I am no two-legg'd creature else.

sp.speaker: Sir Gold. Rich.
sp.p: But I bought you velvet to gard it withall.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: Yes, that's true, an old black velvet Jerkin without sleeves, that had belonged to one of Queen Elizabeth her learned Counsel in the Law of blessed Memory, primo of Her Reign, and you bought it of an old Broker at Nottingham; and as I am a true Christian woman, if our Neigh|bour Botcher could almost few it on, it was so mortified.

sp.speaker: Sir Gold. Rich.
sp.p: I bought you shooes, and ribbons to tie them withall.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: Look Gentlefolks, a pair of wet-leather shooes, that have given me a Cold, and two leather points that he calls ribbons, like a lying false man.

sp.speaker: Sir Gold Rich.
sp.p: I am sure I bought you stockins and garters.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: Old Doncaster-stockins, that I was sain to wash my self with a little borrow'd sope, and they were footed with yellow fustion too, and the garters he talks of were lists of cloth, which a Taylor gave me for my New-years-gift, and I cannot chuse but grieve to see his unkindnesse; I gave you satisfaction often, but you never satisfied me, I will take it upon my death.

sp.speaker: Sir Gold. Rich.
sp.p: Go Gill Flirt, pack away hence.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: Nay that puts me in mind of the Pedlars pack you pro|mis'd me, and I never had so much bought as that I might whissle for them; but I will follow thee to Hell, but I will have something more out of thee than I have had, or else I will make all the Town ring of me.

sp.speaker: Sir Gold. Rich.
sp.p: Here Beadles, take her to the Correction-house, Bridewell, and let her be punished.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: Is it so, thou miscreant? well, I thought to be thy Bride, and not Bridewel, I never thought it in my conscience.

sp.speaker: Lord Title,
sp.p: Pray stay.

div.stage: The Lord Title whispers to Thom. Purveyor, then turns to Mall Mean-bred.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Mall, although you deceived me, and broke your promise, you I will not only save you from the punishment you were to suffer at the Cor|rection-house, but I will give thee a Husband here, lusty Thom. Purveyor, to whom, for taking thee to Wife, I will give him a lease of fifty pounds a year. Here Tom, take her and go marry her.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: Heaven bless your Honour.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Come Mall, let us go Wed, for fifty pounds a year is better than thy Maiden-head.
